nombre de John Berta

e 2008 23:07

Asunto: Re: [nihontostudy] =
Waki in Argentina

 

Hi Maximo;

You have posed a difficult problem with n=
o clear answer. 
This however is quite normal when dealing with Japanese sw=
ords, there never
seems to be a simple answer.

There were a number of Miha=
ra smiths who were named Masaie and signed
Masaie.

The Mihara were divided=
 onto two groups based on their work styles and the
period they worked,

In=
 the Ko Mihara of the Kamakura period, circa 1300, the founder of the
Mihar=
a school was named Masaie.

The work style of the Ko Mihara was koshi sori,=
 with high and wide shinogi,
and iori mune. 
They made mostly tachi and tan=
to with a few shoto. 
The hada I have seen are a tight ko-itame and the col=
or of the ji is fairly
dark
and there is ji nie and there is utsuri present=
. The hamon is mostly a
narrow suguha, the nioi is wide and deep. and there=
 is ashi and sometimes
yo. 
The boshi is ko maru or o maru on a small kissa=
ki. The nakago is ha agiri
kurijiri. 
The mei is usually cut in the center =
of the nakago, cut with a fine chisel
but the kanji are large and deep cut.=


The Sue Mihara worked in the Muromachi period from the end of the Namboku=
cho
period. 
They made mostly katana, wakizashi and tanto. 
The quality of =
their work was not of the standard of the earlier generations
and was infer=
ior. 
They made mostly shinogi zukiri blades and the style and shape of the=
 blades
was similar to the Ko Mihara, but not as elegant or well proportion=
ed. 
They tempered in a suguha as did the earlier smiths but it is wider an=
d also
a gunome midare. 
Quite often there is usually utsuri present and bl=
ades with very little or
no activity in the ha are the most common. 
The me=
i is cut smaller and not as deep as the earlier generations. and are
cut cl=
oser to the mune, and the mei are longer.

In general the older blades are =
more elegant and better proportioned and the
ji is much darker.

I hope thi=
s helps a little.

John
